title: Search in a Binary Search Tree

solutions.name: recursiveSolution
solutions.code:
const recursiveSolution = (root, val) => {
  if (root == null) {
    return null;
  }
  if (val === root.val) {
    return root;
  }
  if (val < root.val) {
    return recursiveSolution(root.left, val);
  }
  return recursiveSolution(root.right, val);
};

testResults.name: Example 1
Example 2

notes:
1. Search in a Binary Search Tree
  • Difficulty: easy
  • Tags: tree, binary-search-tree, binary-tree
  • Description:
  • You are given the root of a binary search tree (BST) and an integer val.
  • Find the node in the BST that the node's value equals val and return the subtree rooted with that node. If such a node does not exist, return null.
  • Examples:
    1. Input: root = [4,2,7,1,3], val = 2
  • Output: [2,1,3]
    1. Input: root = [4,2,7,1,3], val = 5
  • Output: []
  • Constraints:
    • The number of nodes in the tree is in the range [1, 5000].
    • 1 <= Node.val <= 10^7
    • root is a binary search tree.
    • 1 <= val <= 10^7
